Hi,

I have read more about unit testing than actually doing it so bear tha=
t
in mind - apparently, once the developers have got used to writing unit
t=
ests, the time taken to write code+unit tests is shorter than just
writing =
the code. The reason being that you end up writing 'just enough'
to get the=
 job done because you have tests.

Also, it is not recommended to split est=
imates into 2 parts like that.
Unit testing and code-writing are one task.
=

Hopefully, someone with more experience will back these comments up.

Chee=
rs

Rakesh
